awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Visual Attention in an Invertebrate Predator
awd_abstract_narration:
All visual animals face the problem of distinguishing relevant from distracting stimuli quickly and efficiently. One way that visual systems accomplish this task is through selective attention, where an animal attends to a portion of the available visual stimuli at a time. Tiny jumping spiders have microminiature eyes that are nearly as acute as a human's and, like humans, pays attention and discriminates among visual targets. This project investigates how jumping spiders pay attention to and identify moving visual objects.  The simplicity of the jumping spider eye and brain makes it easier to learn how the brain's neural networks "compute" visual movement and object identification, than in humans.  In humans AND jumping spiders, selective visual attention is measured by rapid movements of their eyes to focus on targets of interest. This study employs an innovative eyetracker to measure the direction of a spider's gaze as it views video images. In addition, neural techniques are used to measure the activity of the spider's brain while its gaze is being monitored: specific parts of the brain respond differentially to particular images and sounds. Thus, it is possible to see both what engages a spider's visual attention as well as how different stimuli are interpreted. Understanding this elegant, miniaturized and extremely effective visual system will be of interest to roboticists and engineers, for whom micro-miniaturization of biosensors is a premium in small, self-autonomous robots. In addition, the PI will train a graduate student, a postdoc, and undergraduates, and will create videos for a project called "Faces and Voices of Science" that highlight the personal stories of researchers from different backgrounds. The videos will be made available online for teachers and professors to incorporate in lectures.


Visual animals face the problem of distinguishing relevant from distracting stimuli quickly and efficiently.  One way to do this is through selective attention, where the animal attends to only part of the visual field at a time, through a process of saccadic eye movements and selective target scan.  This is true for humans and at the behavioral level seems true for jumping spiders.  These spiders are highly visual and are among the rare invertebrate animals that have moveable eyes.  The PIs have developed two novel technologies that allow a comprehensive study of selective visual attention.  These include an innovative spider eyetracker can monitor with precision a spider's eye movements in real time as they scan a stimulus image and the first electrophysiological recordings in the brain of a living spider as it observes visual stimuli. The eyetracker will be deployed to monitor eye movements while simultaneously recordings from single units in the brain are recorded.  The PIs will thus test explicit hypotheses about visual attention, eye movements, and correlated brain activity.  These include "bottom-up" stimulus-driven attentional processes by testing how different visual stimuli influence eye movements and neural processes in the brain, as well as "top-down" processes by presenting cross-modal cues and measuring eye movements and neural processes as the spider searches for relevant stimuli among distractors.

por.por_cntn:
Jumping spiders have remarkable vision for a tiny organism, with eight eyes that together provide a nearly 360? field of view. They acquire, analyze, and rapidly respond to all this visual input with a brain about the size of a sesame seed, so they offer an excellent model for understanding visual processing under severe limitations. One way in which spiders streamline information gathering is to divide their eyes into two types: the forward-facing principal eyes are moveable and can be selectively directed at different areas of the visual field, and are well adapted to examining objects, while three pairs of secondary eyes serve as motion detectors. 

 

We used a series of novel techniques to further our understanding of how spiders allocate their attention to different kinds of visual input. First, we used a specialized eyetracker that allows us to determine with precision where the principal eyes are directed, and developed Deep Lab Cut as a method to analyze retinal positions. Second, with UMass colleagues, we developed and refined neural recording techniques that allowed us to measure the neural activity in the spider brain as we track its eye movement, including dual recordings of the principal eye lamina (early in visual processing) and the arcuate body region (later in visual processing). Third, we developed new techniques for neural tract tracing in order to map the connectivity between the different eyes and the central processing area. Fourth, with a different set of UMass colleagues, we developed high pressure liquid chromatography to assess neuromodulator release under different conditions. Finally, we developed a number of new behavioral assays using freely moving spiders in arena trials. Some of our data are very complex and are still being analyzed, so we describe highlights here. 

Attention can be driven by "bottom up" processes, such as features of the stimuli, as well as "top down" processes, such as the desire to find a particular item in the visual field. Spiders' attention is drawn by "bottom up" characteristics of the stimulus: for example, we found that spiders attend more to lines held at certain angles that seem to mimic the legs of other spiders. In addition, stimulus characteristics influence how the eyes interact. The forward-facing pair of secondary eyes share a field of view with the moveable principal eyes, and direct their gaze to newly appearing stimuli. This is not purely reflexive, however: whether the principal eyes redirect to a distractor depends both on the form of stimulus they are examining and the nature of the distractor. Stimulus characteristics also influence brain activity. When presented with images of palatable prey, unpalatable prey, conspecifics, heterospecific salticids, predators, and abstract shapes, each with multiple exemplars, the central brain was more active when presented with palatable prey and suppressed with unpalatable prey. This region showed increased activity even when presented with very simplified versions of prey. Together, these results plus others show that spiders attend to stimulus features?even simple ones?very closely, as shown by both their eye movements and brain activity.

In a series of experiments, we also exposed spiders to different stimuli that might influence their "top down" expectations of what they might see. When we exposed spiders to either the sound of a predatory wasp, or to the pheromones of conspecifics, we did indeed see a rapid and pronounced increase in eye movements. In arena experiments, we also saw that males increased their activity rate. However, we saw little evidence that the spiders were primed to look for particular stimuli (i.e., spiders primed with a wasp sound were not more likely to fixate their gaze on wasp images). We thus conclude that these cross-modal stimuli induce arousal but that (thus far) we have no evidence of directed visual search.

The project provided research experiences for numerous undergraduates and supported two UMass PhD students and a technician, as well as visiting graduate students from Sweden, Brazil, and Singapore. We presented numerous talks about spiders for scientific societies, university seminars, school groups, local naturalist groups, science for the public series, and retirement communities. We also made our equipment and techniques available to visiting researchers. We created some resources for researchers to share profiles of scientists from marginalized groups.

 


Last Modified: 06/20/2023
Modified by: Elizabeth M Jakob

Image
  • (A) A jumping spider's moveable principal eyes and forward-facing pair of secondary eyes (the anterior lateral eyes or ALE). (B) The boomerang-shaped principal-eye retinas examine a cricket image while ignoring an appearing disk, visible to the ALE. Spiders examining a disk redirect to a new disk.
    E. Jakob
    Copyrighted
    Elizabeth M Jakob
    Jumping spider eyes
